channel.title: Physics on Archibald
channel.description: Recent content in Physics on Archibald

item.title: The Government Said It's Real. Physics Went Quiet. That Silence Is the Story.
item.description:
The United States government spent decades telling you there was nothing there.

Then, in June 2021, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence released a preliminary assessment of 144 military UAP encounters. Of those 144, exactly one was explained. The other 143 could not be identified with high confidence. Eighteen of them featured objects that “appeared to remain stationary in winds aloft, move against the wind, maneuver abruptly, or move at considerable speed, without discernible means of propulsion.”

item.title: His Water Work Was Real. His Energy Claims Weren't. The Confiscation Proved Neither.
item.description:
Viktor Schauberger spent his early life watching water.

Not as a physicist — he was an Austrian forest warden, from a family that had been forest custodians in Upper Austria for generations — father, grandfather, great-grandfather and further back, centuries of the same work. His formal education ended early. What he had instead was time: decades of walking river valleys, watching how trout held their position in fast current, noticing how spring water behaved differently from summer water, observing the way certain streams moved logs efficiently while others ground them to pieces against the banks.

item.title: Sixty-Five Billion Per Second. You Don't Notice. Neither Does the Earth.
item.description:
Sixty-five billion solar neutrinos pass through every square centimeter of your hand every second.

You don’t notice. The Sun produces them in the nuclear reactions that keep it burning, and they travel outward at nearly the speed of light, and eight minutes later they reach Earth, and they go straight through it. The rock. The water. The iron core. You. The planet is transparent to neutrinos the way a window is transparent to light, except less so — a neutrino would require a light-year of lead to have better than even odds of hitting anything. The Earth is not an obstacle. The Earth is a mild suggestion.

item.title: Time Only Goes One Way. Nobody Knows Why.
item.description:
Time only goes one way.

You already knew that. Your coffee gets cold. Your eggs don’t unscramble. Your dead grandmother doesn’t come back. You knew this before you knew the word “entropy.” It’s written into everything — into the fact that your memories are of the past, not the future, into the fact that you know which way to hold a video to make it look fake.

Here’s what you probably didn’t know: the laws of physics don’t see it that way.

item.title: The Universe Is 95% Unknown. The Free Energy People Say They've Got the Other 95%.
item.description:
Let’s start with the admission.

In 2018, the Planck satellite collaboration released its final analysis of the cosmic microwave background, the oldest light in the universe, relic radiation from 380,000 years after the Big Bang. The results said this: ordinary matter makes up 5% of the universe. Everything you can see, touch, weigh, or measure. Stars, planets, gas, dust, you. Five percent.

The other 95% is something we don’t understand.

item.title: Einstein Lost This Argument. The Quantum Healers Still Don't Know What It Was About.
item.description:
In October 2022, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics to Alain Aspect, John Clauser, and Anton Zeilinger “for experiments with entangled photons, establishing the violation of Bell inequalities and pioneering quantum information science.”

Translation: three physicists spent their careers proving that the universe cannot be locally real.

If you’ve heard about this from a quantum healer, I need you to stop and read carefully. They got the wrong lesson.

item.title: Quantum Mechanics Works Perfectly. Nobody Knows What It Means.
item.description:
Here is the problem in the middle of quantum mechanics that every textbook either skips or lies about.

When you measure a quantum system (an electron’s spin, a photon’s polarization, a particle’s position) the calculation gives you a probability distribution over possible outcomes. You measure. You get one outcome. The probability distribution was right in the statistical sense, over many measurements. But this one measurement gave you this one result. The question quantum mechanics cannot answer is: what happened?

item.title: They Got the Territory Right. This Map Won't Get You There.
item.description:
Start with the actual claim, not the version that gets made fun of.

Roger Penrose is not proposing that your neurons are tiny quantum computers that generate feelings through spooky action at a distance. That is a parody of his argument and it has been very convenient for people who don’t want to engage with the actual argument. The actual argument is harder.

In 1989, Penrose published “The Emperor’s New Mind.” The central claim: human consciousness involves non-computable processes. The argument is mathematical, not mystical. It goes like this. Gödel’s first incompleteness theorem says that any sufficiently powerful formal system contains true statements that the system cannot prove. But Penrose adds a step, building on Lucas: human mathematicians can see that the Gödel sentence is true. We can step outside the formal system and recognize the truth that no algorithm within the system can reach. If that’s right, then consciousness is doing something no algorithm can do. Therefore consciousness is not algorithmic. Therefore it requires something physics hasn’t accounted for yet.

item.title: He Was Right About the Territory. The Map Is Still Being Drawn.
item.description: In 1968, Herbert Fröhlich published a paper in the International Journal of Quantum Chemistry proposing that biological macromolecules could exhibit long-range coherent quantum oscillations, driven by metabolic energy, analogous to Bose-Einstein condensation. The prediction was specific: above a critical threshold of energy input, a biological system driven far from thermal equilibrium would channel excess energy into a single quantum mode, producing collective oscillations in the terahertz range. He called it a condensate. The community eventually called it Fröhlich coherence.

item.title: NASA Spent Six Hundred Thousand Dollars and Never Ran the Test. The Inventor Won't Tell You Why.
item.description: In the early 1990s, a Russian materials scientist at Tampere University of Technology in Finland claimed that a rotating superconducting ceramic disk reduced the weight of objects placed above it by somewhere between 0.05 and 0.5 percent. His name was Evgeny Podkletnov. The claim was specific, the mechanism was unspecified, the effect was small enough that it might have been measurement error, and nobody in mainstream physics had a theoretical framework that would predict anything like it.

item.title: The Universe Has Been Proving Einstein Right Through Your Chest All Morning. You Were Worried About Chemtrails.
item.description:
October 15, 1991. Dugway Proving Ground, Utah. The Fly’s Eye detector recorded a cosmic ray event at approximately 3.2 times 10^20 electron volts.

Let me put that in units your nervous system can actually process. What does 3.2 times 10^20 electron volts mean to a human?

A single proton arrived at Earth’s upper atmosphere carrying the kinetic energy of a baseball moving at ninety kilometers per hour. One proton. One subatomic particle. Baseball-throw energy, concentrated in a thing smaller than thought. It hit the atmosphere and the atmosphere won, obviously. The proton annihilated into a cascade of secondary particles that spread across a square kilometer of Utah desert before anything could catch it. But for the duration of its approach, that proton existed. It was real. It came from somewhere.

item.title: The Navy Published Their Nothing. Here's Why That's the Tell.
item.description:
The Biefeld-Brown effect is real. Capacitors under high voltage produce thrust. This is reproducible, measurable, and documented. You can build one in your kitchen if you’re comfortable working around high voltages, which you probably shouldn’t be, but the physics works.

The question — and it’s been the question since Thomas Townsend Brown started running experiments in the 1920s — is whether that thrust is ion wind or something stranger.

Ion wind is what happens when you ionize air near an electrode and the resulting ion flow drags neutral air molecules with it. It’s real, well-understood, and completely mundane. The “something stranger” is what Brown spent sixty years claiming: a direct coupling between electrostatic fields and gravity. Electrogravitics. A reactionless drive that would make rockets look like steam engines.

item.title: One Bad Afternoon. Twenty-Three Years of Consequences.
item.description:
Birmingham International Airport, 1984.

A small elevated shuttle is running a 600-metre track at 42 km/h, carrying passengers between the terminal and the railway station. No wheels touching rails. No combustion. A linear induction motor — a horizontal electromagnetic field dragging a reaction plate through space — doing what wheels and pistons used to do.

The world’s first commercial maglev people mover. Running. Doing its job.

The man most responsible for the engineering principles underneath it wasn’t there. He was eight years into the institutional exile that had started with one bad afternoon in 1974.

item.title: The Planet Is a Resonator. Stop Making It Weird.
item.description: The Earth has a resonant frequency. It’s 7.83 Hz. This was predicted by a German physicist named Winfried Otto Schumann in 1952. He and his collaborator H.L. König published the first measurements in 1954. More comprehensive experimental confirmation followed from Balser and Wagner between 1960 and 1963. It has been measured continuously at monitoring stations around the world ever since. It is one of the most thoroughly documented electromagnetic phenomena in geophysics.

item.title: Chapman Got Conferences. Birkeland Got a Banknote.
item.description: Norway put Kristian Birkeland on their 200 krone note in 1994. On the front: his face, the aurora borealis behind him, his terrella experiment — a miniature magnetized Earth he’d built in a vacuum chamber to demonstrate how solar electrons create auroral light. On the back: a map of the Arctic polar region, with a ring drawn around the magnetic dip pole, marking exactly where the currents he’d predicted flow into the ionosphere.

item.title: The Physics Nobel Called It Fraud. The Astrophysicist Found What He Said He'd Find.
item.description:
In February 2021, Randell Mills demonstrated a plasma device in Washington DC that he claimed was generating 100,000 watts of continuous steam power. He called a press release. He showed the device. He made the claim.

Then the physics community continued not caring.

This is, roughly, the shape of the Randell Mills story for the last thirty-four years. Something happens. A number gets announced. Credentialed observers note something unusual. Then: silence, sarcasm, the occasional Nobel laureate dropping the word “fraud,” and everything continuing exactly as before.

item.title: The Word Died in 1989. The Experiment Didn't.
item.description:
The press conference was the crime. Not the science - the press conference.

March 23, 1989. Martin Fleischmann and Stanley Pons stand in front of cameras at the University of Utah and announce they’ve achieved nuclear fusion at room temperature. In a glass jar. With palladium electrodes and heavy water. The physics establishment’s reaction landed somewhere between “excuse me?” and “how dare you.”

Nobody cracks down on a failed experiment. What they cracked down on was the venue. You don’t announce nuclear fusion without peer review. You don’t do it at a press conference. You don’t do it before independent replication is in. These were genuine violations of genuine norms and the physics community had a real point.

item.title: Feynman Said Sorry. Fusion Physics Didn't Get the Memo.
item.description:
Here is a thing that actually happened: Richard Feynman — the Feynman, the bongo-playing, safe-cracking, Nobel Prize-winning conscience of 20th century physics — wrote an apology letter in 1986 to a researcher named Kenneth Shoulders.

The subject: stable electron clusters containing ten billion electrons.

Feynman’s initial position: impossible. Coulomb repulsion would tear them apart instantly.

Feynman’s revised position, after seeing Shoulders’ data: “is indeed possible.”

That letter should have changed everything. You already know it didn’t. But do you know why?

item.title: Seventy Thousand Degrees in a Water Glass
item.description:
They discovered it with sonar equipment in 1934. They said they had more important matters. They did.

There is a bubble of air at the center of a glass flask. Someone turns on a speaker. It expands — swells to fifty microns, about half the width of a human hair. Then the acoustic wave flips. The pressure outside reverses. The atmosphere decides it’s done being polite.

What happens next takes less than a nanosecond.

item.title: String Theory: Physics' Forty-Year Con Job
item.description:
They sold us eleven dimensions and delivered zero predictions. Welcome to the greatest intellectual pyramid scheme in physics history, where mathematical beauty became the excuse for scientific bankruptcy, and two generations of brilliant physicists got eaten alive by a framework that can’t be tested, can’t be falsified, and somehow — SOMEHOW — keeps getting funding.

Forty years. Forty years of conferences and textbooks and tenure committees selecting for string theory fluency. What did we get? Ten to the power of 500 possible universes. That’s not a Theory of Everything. That’s a confession that you have no fucking idea what’s happening, written in sufficiently exotic notation that you need a PhD to recognize the confession.

item.title: What Happens When You Look
item.description:
Quantum mechanics is the most accurate scientific theory in human history. The Dirac equation predicts the magnetic moment of the electron to 12 decimal places. The Standard Model has been confirmed to parts per trillion. No theory has been more precisely validated by experiment.

None of this tells you what happens when you look.

The wavefunction collapse problem – what occurs when a quantum system is measured – has been unresolved since Heisenberg in 1927. Not unresolved as in “partially understood, more work needed.” Unresolved as in: physicists actively disagree about whether anything happens at all, whether the word “happens” is even applicable, and whether asking the question constitutes legitimate physics or the kind of philosophy they agreed to stop doing.
